titleStmt.title: Nuntius a mortuis: or, a messenger from the dead. That is, a stupendous and dreadfull colloquie, distinctly and alternately heard by divers, betwixt the ghosts of Henry the Eight, and Charles the First, both Kings of England, who lye entombed in the church of Windsor. Wherein, (as with a pencill from heaven) is liquidly (from head to foot) set forth, the whole series of the judgements of God, upon the sinnes of these unfortunate jslands. Translated out of the Latine copie, by G.T.
Nuntius a mortuis. English
titleStmt.author: Perrinchief, Richard, 1623?-1673.

titleStmt.title: Nuntius a mortuis: or, a messenger from the dead. That is, a stupendous and dreadfull colloquie, distinctly and alternately heard by divers, betwixt the ghosts of Henry the Eight, and Charles the First, both Kings of England, who lye entombed in the church of Windsor. Wherein, (as with a pencill from heaven) is liquidly (from head to foot) set forth, the whole series of the judgements of God, upon the sinnes of these unfortunate jslands. Translated out of the Latine copie, by G.T.
Nuntius a mortuis. English
titleStmt.author: Perrinchief, Richard, 1623?-1673.
Henry VIII, King of England, 1491-1547.
Charles I, King of England, 1600-1649.

notesStmt.note: Latin verse on p. 32 signed: R.P., i.e. Richard Perrinchief.

Copy filmed at UMI microfilm Early English Books 1641-1700 reel 2317 bound and filmed after both: Cooke, Edward. Certain passages which happened at Newport, (Wing C5997). And: Raleigh, Carew. Observations upon some particular persons and passages (Wing R149).
Reproduction of original in the Newberry Library.
